Comment: Carter didn't give up the farm or the warehouse business. He didn't even put them in a blind trust.  He put his interest in them in an open trust. He continued to receive trust income, and the trustee was his close friend Charles Kirbo, who was an advisor of his and often stayed at the White House.  There was a Special Counsel investigation into whether any trust funds were diverted into his campaign. The investigation did not find wrongdoing in that regard, but it did uncover that Billy Carter had obtained a large loan for the businesses from the National Bank of Georgia shortly before President Carter appointed Bert Lance, the President of the National Bank of Georgia, to serve as director of the OMB.  Carter also had to bail out the businesses while President, and they were over $1 million in debt by the time his Presidency was over.
